docs.lead_paragraph: The autonomous vehicles developed by Google pose enormous challenges for the world of law and insurance, speakers at a symposium said.

headline.seo: Google’s Autonomous Vehicles Draw Skepticism at Legal Symposium
headline.main: Collision in the Making Between Self-Driving Cars and How the World Works
headline.print_headline: Collision in the Making Between Self-Driving Cars and How the World Works

docs.abstract: Speakers at a symposium say the autonomous vehicles developed by Google pose enormous challenges for the world of law and insurance; Google and automobile makers are lobbying for legislative changes to permit autonomous vehicles on the nation's roads.
docs.snippet: The autonomous vehicles developed by Google pose enormous challenges for the world of law and insurance, speakers at a symposium said.

headline.main: Taking Up Taxes on the Campaign Trail

docs.abstract: Newt Gingrich is exactly the sort of millionaire “small business” owner that Republicans are really trying to protect when they sloganeer about “job creators.”
docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich is exactly the sort of millionaire “small business” owner that Republicans are really trying to protect when they sloganeer about “job creators.”

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican politicians talk a great deal about saving small businesses, and routinely play the mom-and-pop card when arguing against raising taxes, or charging a decent minimum wage, or providing everyone with access to health insurance. Last year, when the Senate was debating how to pay for a renewal of the payroll tax cut, Democrats proposed a surcharge on incomes over $1 million a year. Republicans screamed that this would hurt small businesses, and hence the economy, because small businesses are "job creators."

headline.main: Taking Up Taxes on the Campaign Trail

docs.abstract: Newt Gingrich is exactly the sort of millionaire "small business" owner that Republicans are really trying to protect when they sloganeer about "job creators."
docs.snippet: Newt Gingrich is exactly the sort of millionaire "small business" owner that Republicans are really trying to protect when they sloganeer about "job creators."

docs.lead_paragraph: Private chefs prepared to cook anything, elegant surroundings and even butlers are among the amenities in lavish suites of some hospitals.

headline.seo: Chefs, Butlers and Marble Baths - Not Your Average Hospital Room
headline.main: Chefs, Butlers, Marble Baths: Hospitals Vie for the Affluent
headline.print_headline: Chefs, Butlers, Marble Baths: Hospitals Vie for the Affluent

docs.abstract: Hospitals around the country are increasingly offering luxury amenities to compete for wealthy patients willing to pay extra, even as the federal government cuts back hospital reimbursement in pursuit of a more universal and affordable American medical system; hospitals are leery of drawing attention to their efforts to cater to the rich at a time when many urban hospital are lobbing against cuts in federal spending and highlighting their role as nonprofit teaching institutions that serve the poor.
docs.snippet: Private chefs prepared to cook anything, elegant surroundings and even butlers are among the amenities in lavish suites of some hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans spend more than patients in any other country, but with very mixed results.

headline.seo: The Money Traps in U.S. Health Care
headline.main: The Money Traps in U.S. Health Care
headline.print_headline: The Money Traps In U.S. Health Care

docs.abstract: Editorial examines why, despite the fact that America has the highest health care costs, the results are not much greater than other advanced nations that spend less on health care.
docs.snippet: Americans spend more than patients in any other country, but with very mixed results.

docs.lead_paragraph: The death of a spouse rewrites the rules of a family in ways I never could have imagined.

headline.seo: Watching Them Watching Me — Modern Love

docs.abstract: Dean E Murphy Modern Love column describes how the death of his beloved wife deepened his relationship with their three sons.

docs.lead_paragraph: The new divide in America is between a smaller mobile class and one that can’t quite pack up and go.

headline.main: A Mess on the Ladder of Success

docs.abstract: Adam Davidson It's the Economy column highlights the fact that Americans are no longer as willing to move around the country in search of jobs; asserts that in part it is because there are only a few industries that are growing and actively recruiting candidates from across the country, and most of these candidates have some kind of specialized higher education; argues that it is in the country's interest to make sure that as many people as possible are able to move toward opportunity.
docs.snippet: The new divide in America is between a smaller mobile class and one that can’t quite pack up and go.

docs.lead_paragraph: Why does an appendectomy in Germany cost roughly a quarter what it costs in the United States? Or an M.R.I. scan cost less than a third as much, on average, in Canada? Americans continue to spend more on health care than patients anywhere else. In 2009, we spent $7,960 per person, twice as much as France, which is known for providing very good health services. And for all that spending, we get very mixed results -- some superb, some average, some inferior -- compared with other advanced nations. Why this is true isn't easily answered.

headline.main: The Money Traps In U.S. Health Care

docs.snippet: Why does an appendectomy in Germany cost roughly a quarter what it costs in the United States? Or an M.R.I. scan cost less than a third as much, on average, in Canada?     Americans continue to spend more on health care than patients anywhere else....
